Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Effects of Lesser Spoken Language Access in Immigration Court

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research examines how scarcity of interpreting services shapes access to justice in immigration courts through an ethnographic case study. Though respondents have a right to an interpreter at all hearings, interpreting services for lesser spoken or rare languages are minimally available. As a result, respondents frequently waive interpretation services. The research analyzes how courtroom authorities attempt to uphold language access plans that prescribe best practices while availability of quality language services remains limited on the ground.

The research applies language and communication theory to institutional policies through first person interviews and observations of courtroom proceedings. Expanding on conclusions from over a year of preliminary fieldwork, the research observes how (1) scarcity of interpreting resources creates an economy of labor between judges, lawyers, and non-government legal aid to help respondents understand proceedings; (2) courtroom spaces with limited language services allow immigration judges to innovate communicative strategies to compensate for gaps in respondent understanding; (3) under the pressure of limited resources, judges rely on both institutional and personal beliefs about language, and linguistic comprehension, to make decisions about the necessity of interpreting services. This long term ethnographic study of immigration court will contribute to sociolegal and anthropological scholarship on mobility and citizenship by examining the critical component of language access in immigration adjudication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In October 2015, the Department of Justice private contract for providing language services for the nation’s 54 immigration courts changed hands from a long line of established language service agencies to a military contractor that had little experience with domestic projects. Within months, interpreters in Los Angeles, California were protesting a wide range of labor violations and their misclassification as independent contractors instead of employees. Interpreters’ labor organizing draws attention to a decades old professional struggle to assert the fundamental value of their work to legal institutions, as well as the contractor’s policies that limit their ability to perform well in the courtroom and litigants’ due process rights. The research confirms these claims, and further shows that these problems are rooted in neoliberal ideologies upholding government privatization and corporate use of independent contracting. In this way, the dissertation reveals the chain of influence of neoliberal policies – from the federal contract for language services, to contractor’s labor practices and their impact on interpreters’ ability to perform their day to day work, to the inconsistent quality of interpreting services in the courtroom. 

In order to show this chain of consequences I traced the work that professionals do with language itself, both to help respondents understand proceedings and navigate the trial process and to themselves understand respondents in order to move cases forward. The corpus of observational data spans three years of policy change, hundreds over hearings conducted by 22 judges, 42 languages. Observational data collection is complete, and the corpus is coded for a number of recurring patterns of speech and discussion that associate with labor concerns for interpreters, including discussions of interpreting quality, interpreter professionalism, and professional responsibility for communicating with litigants. Courtroom observations are considered alongside in-depth interviews with professionals in the immigration law community. Interviews with interpreters, lawyers, and judges are coded with attention to the linguistic challenges of their day to day work, in particular, to communicate across languages within the limitations of courtroom practice policy. I contextualize these observations and interviews with federal, court, and company policy that impacts language access for a structural analysis of these microcosmic scenarios.

Taken together, these data show that this “linguistic labor,” the efforts professionals put into linguistic interaction, is unevenly recognized, distributed, and compensated across the hierarchy of courtroom officers. I found that these linguistic contributions were not formally considered labor, and unrecognized and unpaid day to day linguistic work goes extracted as surplus value. I observed and uncovered how courtroom officials’ own ideas about language naturalize linguistic labor, and how interpreters are re-shaping these metalinguistic discourses to better suit their labor organizing efforts. I conducted a close analysis of a focused to show the consequences of naturalizing linguistic labor, in particular, the unequal distribution of access to justice across litigants’ language and race.  As a result, the research shows the importance of the labor power in language across scales of sociopolitical power in addition to expanding our understanding of language and social life. The implications are broad-ranging across professions and social groups globally - the labor of language is unequally distributed across gender, race, class, and caste, in contexts of state, medical, military, and corporate enterprise; and scholars in a wide range of inquiry can benefit from this added frame of analysis.

A labor framework allowed me to track how linguistic labor as it is distributed across professional roles, race, gender, and language, finding that lower ranking professionals, who tended to be women of color, bear an unequal amount of linguistic labor. I found that these women of color were additionally the most replaceable labor - the legal and courtroom culture had severely devalued the labor of qualified interpreters and used unqualified replacements when they demanded fair treatment. Unqualified bilingual individuals and legal professionals, both untrained in assessing linguistic comprehension, were often left to rely on racial cues to make decisions about whether or not litigants understood what was happening. The study is additionally unique in this persecptive given that typically, anthropologists discuss the social associations between language and race in contexts of accent and dialect, where this project investigates this connection in a multilingual setting, isolating factors of region, ethnicity, and class in order to privilege an investigation into racially driven perceptions of speakers.
